title: Bollinger band styling breaks plot
body:
The bb styling in freqtrade/plot/plotting.py does not render as expected.
```python
    if 'bb_lowerband' in data and 'bb_upperband' in data:
        bb_lower = go.Scattergl(
            x=data.date,
            y=data.bb_lowerband,
            name='BB lower',
            line={'color': 'rgba(255,255,255,0)'},
        )
        bb_upper = go.Scattergl(
            x=data.date,
            y=data.bb_upperband,
            name='BB upper',
            fill="tonexty",
            fillcolor="rgba(0,176,246,0.2)",
            line={'color': 'rgba(255,255,255,0)'},
        )
        fig.add_trace(bb_lower, 1, 1)
        fig.add_trace(bb_upper, 1, 1)
```

Given I am calling the following from a jupyter notebook:
```python
chart = generate_candlestick_graph(pair=pair,
                                       data=data,
                                       trades=trades,
                                       indicators1=['bb_upperband', 'bb_lowerband'],
                                       indicators2=[])
```

`chart.show(renderer="browser")` produces:
![Screen Shot 2019-09-22 at 6 58 22 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3618365/65395584-01073700-dd6b-11e9-93a5-4d2733d9b303.png)

When the above code is removed, this is produced:

![Screen Shot 2019-09-22 at 6 49 44 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3618365/65395554-66a6f380-dd6a-11e9-809b-12427b324081.png)


In addition to the problems rendering, the automatic addition of the indicators is not obvious. I understand offering some defaults for the user, but if duplicates are specified in `indicators1[]`, it is not obvious why the legend contains duplicates without looking at the source.
![Screen Shot 2019-09-22 at 7 02 29 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3618365/65395622-90144f00-dd6b-11e9-920c-becf26e32fda.png)

I can create a PR that removes the offending lines if that is helpful.

title: Plot-scripts require --datadir
body:
## Describe your environment

  * Python Version: 3.7
  * Branch: Develop
  * Last Commit ID:  962d487edb0d28f95d6395c09189a333c436fd20
  
## Describe the problem:

Currently, `freqtrade plot-dataframe` does require either a valid configuration (`--config` or `config.json` in cwd - or `--datadir user_data/data/bittrex` to find the backtest data.
This is because without one of these, the exchange is not known, which is a requirement to find the data in the datadir.

## Possible fixes

* Error and point out that one of the 2 conditions have to be met
* add `--exchange` parameter as alternative (including the above)

* ... other ideas?

title: Improve stoploss on exchange handling

labels.name: Stoploss
labels.description: Related to stoploss

body:
## Summary
Failed stoploss-on-exchange orders should be handled gracefully.

Fixes #1557, Fixes #1918 (part of this was fixed in #2177).

## Quick changelog

- Extract logic to create a stoploss-order (it was called in 3 places) - (enables easy implementation of #1717  and #1718)
- introduce new sell-type - EmergencySell - to clearly outline sells which were not triggered by the exchange.
- If creating a stoploss-order fails with InvalidOrder (mostly seen as `Order would trigger immediately.`) - we force-sell the pair using a market order (can be changed).


## Review hints:

- best review the first 2 commits seperately - they are simply refactoring to enable the remaining work without code duplication in 3 places.

title: Orders not closing in huobi
body:
## Step 1: Have you search for this issue before posting it?

i saw previous huobi issues but none related to this. 

## Step 2: Describe your environment

  * Operating system: docker / ubuntu
  * Python Version: see below (`python -V`)
  * CCXT version: 1.18.1008 (`pip freeze | grep ccxt`)
  * Branch: Develop
  * Last Commit ID: 6c0c77b3a15b6a672e5c7750e9162b1fae4a8103 (`git log --format="%H" -n 1`)
  
## Step 3: Describe the problem:

Running bot on huobi but when the sell occurs the bot keeps the orders open. The sell takes place on the exchange. Not sure why the bot isn't updating the orders appropriately. I've tried restarting the bot but it keeps the order "open" when they truly have been closed.

title: hyperopt don't use the dataframe indicators of populate_indicators (of curent file) when optimize only roi stoploss
body:
## Step 3: Describe the problem:

when running hyperopt with --spaces roi stoploss the populate_buy_trend use the indicators of i think default_strategy instead of use the indicators of the populate_indicators of the current file.

It raise an keyerror exception because he don't find the indicator.

### Steps to reproduce:

  1. Create a custom indicator in hyperopt populate_indicators 
  2. run hyperopt with --spaces roi stoploss
  3. freqtrade raise a key error because he don't find the indicator in the dataframe.

Have a nice day

If it hasn't been reported, please create a new issue.

title: Exchange.__del__() fails when called on a semi-initialized object

  File "/opt/Projects/freqtrade/freqtrade/exchange/exchange.py", line 272, in validate_timeframes
    timeframes = self._api.timeframes
AttributeError: 'bitstamp' object has no attribute 'timeframes'
```

### Steps to reproduce:

  1. Attempt to use bitstamp
  
### Observed Results:

  * Exchange initialization failed
  * Exchange initialization succeed

### What to do ?
Is there a way to fix this ?
If not, how about a way to have it fail in a little bit nicer fashion ?

title: force sell creates loop trying to set a stoploss on the pair that has been sold

labels.name: Stoploss
labels.description: Related to stoploss

body:
## Step 1: Have you search for this issue before posting it?

Yes, not found.

## Step 2: Describe your environment

Python Version: python3.7
CCXT version: 1.18.551
Branch: Master | Develop
  
## Step 3: Describe the problem:

On binance, I had a pair, ADX, I'm using 12hr candles, so when the bot bought, it pumped 15%, my bot sold as that was ROI, then since the "buy signal" is still lingering it, it bought again (this is reported on #1904 ; I tried force selling it but then after it sold it would not update the database or the state of the pair, so it thinks that it still has the pair, If i try to force sell it again it does not work, I tried a /forcesell all and it was stuck on "stop-loss on limit would execute immediately" as it still think its still trading the same pair ADX
### Steps to reproduce:

1. Bot on binance
2. Forcesell a pair after it sold for ROI on the same buy condition that occurred candle before
3. It will keep the coin and not update
4 . Forcesell again or /forcesell all
  
### Observed Results:

  * What happened? it kept lingering over and over on trying to set a stop-limit order but avoid since it would trigger immediately
  * What did you expect to happen? forcesell should have been done, database updated and kept cycling as usual

### Relevant code exceptions or logs:

  ```

title: Huobi Old ticker data
body:
## Step 1: Have you search for this issue before posting it?

Related to issue with bitfinex to #1889 

## Step 2: Describe your environment

Python Version: python3.7
CCXT version: 1.18.551

title: Avoid sell/buy on same candle
body:
## Step 1: Have you search for this issue before posting it?
Yes. Post related 1850
#
https://github.com/freqtrade/freqtrade/issues/1850

Python Version: python3.7
CCXT version: 1.18.551
Branch: Master | Develop
  
## Step 3: Describe the problem:
Bot using 30m candle. Simple smacross. So far so good, but it seems it bought and since condition to sell was reached on the same candle it bought again after selling. 
### Steps to reproduce:

Its hard to reproduce as the sell condition has to happen on the same candle as the buy condition. 
  
### Observed Results:

What happened? It bought back after selling in profit. 
What should have happened? That it only bought once rather than immediately buying after sell

### Relevant code exceptions or logs:
Sadly systemd is not keeping the whole log so I can't take it from there and I was not saving it on another file. 
![Screenshot_20190603-012154](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5402278/58764082-fea38600-859d-11e9-84df-834b5e25d128.png)

Binance: Buying TNT/BTC
with limit 0.00000374
(0.009040 BTC,78.713 USD)

Binance: Selling TNT/BTC
Limit: 0.00000431
Amount: 2417.00000000
Open Rate: 0.00000374
Current Rate: 0.00000431
Sell Reason: roi
Profit: 15.01% (profit: 0.00135823 BTC / 11.827 USD)

Binance: Buying TNT/BTC
with limit 0.00000431
(0.009137 BTC,79.563 USD)

Binance: Selling TNT/BTC
Limit: 0.00000388
Amount: 2120.00000000
Open Rate: 0.00000431
Current Rate: 0.00000392
Sell Reason: stoploss_on_exchange
Profit: -10.39% (loss: -0.00095014 BTC / -8.273 USD)

As you can see on timestamp it's still the same candle that it bought, so my assumption is that somehow it verifies that the condition happen before and he doesn't understand that hr already sold in profit so he buys again.

Shouldn't it turn the buy condition off in the same pair after roi or stoploss until it happens again?

title: Order cancelled AND fullfilled
body:
## Step 1: Have you search for this issue before posting it?
Yes

## Step 2: Describe your environment

  * Python Version: 3.6.7 (`python -V`)
  * CCXT version: 1.18.516 (`pip freeze | grep ccxt`)
  * Branch: Develop
  * Last Commit ID: 46b1ecc77d53054aed6835d69f9989316422aa78 (`git log --format="%H" -n 1`)
  
## Step 3: Describe the problem:

Exchange: Kraken
In configuration file: "stake_amount": "unlimited",

- Freqtrade makes a limit order


```
2019-05-16 10:00:05,129 - freqtrade.freqtradebot - INFO - Found no buy signals for whitelisted currencies. Trying again..
2019-05-16 10:00:16,095 - freqtrade.freqtradebot - INFO - Buy signal found: about create a new trade with stake_amount: 19.7381 ...
2019-05-16 10:00:16,096 - freqtrade.freqtradebot - INFO - Using Last Ask / Last Price
2019-05-16 10:00:19,401 - freqtrade.rpc.rpc_manager - INFO - Sending rpc message: {'type': buy, 'exchange': 'Kraken', 'pair': 'BTC/EUR', 'limit': 7150.3, 'stake_amount': 19.7381, 'stake_currency': 'EUR', 'fiat_currency': 'EUR'}
2019-05-16 10:00:22,382 - freqtrade.wallets - INFO - Wallets synced.
```

- Kraken cancels the order

```
2019-05-16 10:00:25,471 - freqtrade.rpc.rpc_manager - INFO - Sending rpc message: {'type': status, 'status': 'Unfilled buy order for BTC/EUR canceled on Exchange'}
```

ISSUE:

- Kraken tells FT that the order is canceled

- but Kraken filled the order.
Here is the explaination of the behavior of kraken:
https://support.kraken.com/hc/en-us/articles/235162907-Order-Canceled-due-to-Out-of-Funds-

```
Order Canceled due to "Out of Funds":
It is possible for an order to partially execute (or "fill") if there are insufficient balances in the account for the order to fully execute.
This most commonly occurs when an order is placed for maximum volume. 
[...]
This is because the trading fee was not taken into consideration when placing the order.
```

- But FT has no active trade (cf. telegram /status -> 'no active trade') so it does not seem to be aware that the order were filled

Is that a normal way to act for FT or an issue ?
If freqtrade has no active trade, will it be able to sell the previously bought cryptos ? (perhaps I did not correctly understood the "active trade" definition)

To bypass this issuer, I configured the "stake_amount" parameters a little bit lower than the amount of available currency (currently testing).

Thank you
Xavier

title: Unable to create trade: Available balance is lower than stake amount
body:
## Step 1: Have you search for this issue before posting it?

Yes, found the issue but no solution.

## Step 2: Describe your environment

  * Python Version: Python 3.6.8
  * CCXT version: ccxt==1.18.472
  * Branch: Develop
  * Last Commit ID: 031a63d5c25a38e020970ca2e24843cb39d9a83e
  
## Step 3: Describe the problem:

The BTC balance doesn't update after sell, only update in buy method.

### Steps to reproduce:

  1. Start bot in live mode and put the stake amount more than 50% of your available balance.
  2. Wait bot finish the 1st trade closed and sold sucessfully.
  3. Wait bot search for new trade and find a buy signal.
  
### Observed Results:

 In 3 Step bot can't buy because the balance in bot is outdated, be like the balance not updated after the bot sell the 1st trade, and the balance will be lower than stake because the stake is more than 50% of your balance.

### Relevant code exceptions or logs:

  ```
2019-04-18 22:34:09,688 - unknown - INFO - Searching pairs: ['MITH/BTC', 'ETH/BTC', 'XRP/BTC', 'BCH/BTC', 'ENJ/BTC', 'LTC/BTC', 'FET/BTC', 'EOS/BTC', 'ADA/BTC', 'BAT/BTC', 'CELR/BTC', 'REP/BTC', 'RVN/BTC', 'TRX/BTC', 'ZIL/BTC', 'WTC/BTC', 'VET/BTC', 'DGD/BTC', 'LEND/BTC', 'WABI/BTC', 'NANO/BTC', 'PHX/BTC', 'HOT/BTC', 'TNB/BTC', 'XMR/BTC', 'ICX/BTC', 'NEO/BTC', 'VIB/BTC', 'DENT/BTC', 'DASH/BTC']
2019-04-18 22:34:10,400 - freqtrade.freqtradebot - WARNING - Unable to create trade: Available balance(0.00018994 BTC) is lower than stake amount(0.003 BTC)
2019-04-18 22:34:14,693 - unknown - INFO - Searching pairs: ['MITH/BTC', 'ETH/BTC', 'XRP/BTC', 'BCH/BTC', 'ENJ/BTC', 'LTC/BTC', 'FET/BTC', 'EOS/BTC', 'ADA/BTC', 'BAT/BTC', 'CELR/BTC', 'REP/BTC', 'RVN/BTC', 'TRX/BTC', 'ZIL/BTC', 'WTC/BTC', 'VET/BTC', 'DGD/BTC', 'LEND/BTC', 'WABI/BTC', 'NANO/BTC', 'PHX/BTC', 'HOT/BTC', 'TNB/BTC', 'XMR/BTC', 'ICX/BTC', 'NEO/BTC', 'VIB/BTC', 'DENT/BTC', 'DASH/BTC']
2019-04-18 22:34:15,378 - freqtrade.freqtradebot - WARNING - Unable to create trade: Available balance(0.00018994 BTC) is lower than stake amount(0.003 BTC)

  ```

The real balance when this errors ocurred is 0.00318994 BTC, so the bot not updated after the last sell. I tried myself to fix this error adding the code below in "execute_sell" method in "freqtradebot.py" class:

`self.wallets.update()`

My complete "execute_sell" method in "freqtradebot.py" class is like this:

```
def execute_sell(self, trade: Trade, limit: float, sell_reason: SellType) -> None:

        sell_type = 'sell'
        if sell_reason in (SellType.STOP_LOSS, SellType.TRAILING_STOP_LOSS):
            sell_type = 'stoploss'

        # if stoploss is on exchange and we are on dry_run mode,
        # we consider the sell price stop price
        if self.config.get('dry_run', False) and sell_type == 'stoploss' \
           and self.strategy.order_types['stoploss_on_exchange']:
            limit = trade.stop_loss

        # First cancelling stoploss on exchange ...
        if self.strategy.order_types.get('stoploss_on_exchange') and trade.stoploss_order_id:
            self.exchange.cancel_order(trade.stoploss_order_id, trade.pair)

        # Execute sell and update trade record
        order_id = self.exchange.sell(pair=str(trade.pair),
                                      ordertype=self.strategy.order_types[sell_type],
                                      amount=trade.amount, rate=limit,
                                      time_in_force=self.strategy.order_time_in_force['sell']
                                      )['id']

        trade.open_order_id = order_id
        trade.close_rate_requested = limit
        trade.sell_reason = sell_reason.value
        Trade.session.flush()
		
	# Updating wallets
        self.wallets.update()
		
        self.notify_sell(trade)
```

With my hotfix the problem is gone.

title: Stoploss order unable to be filled due to too low notional amount
body:
I've encountered a problem that my stoploss on exchange order is unable to be filled, because after the price dropping, the minimum order amount is not reached anymore.

Example:
Minimum order size is 0.05 BTC
Buy 1 ETH for 0.05 BTC and set stoploss at 5%
Price drops to 0.475 -> stoploss is triggered
Can't execute order, because minimum order size is not reached.

These are obviously made up values, but this happened to me with ENJ/BTC on Binance.

My proposed solution would be to verify at order creation whether the minimum order size is met including the stoploss.

title: No currency pairs in whitelist
body:
## Step 1: Have you search for this issue before posting it?

Yes !

## Step 2: Describe your environment

  * Python Version: 3.6.7 (`python -V`)
  * CCXT version: 1.18.372  (`pip freeze | grep ccxt`)
  * Branch: Master | Develop
  * Last Commit ID: c8617e70a87cc2835738d5d2bad0cd46dc2e9d68 (`git log --format="%H" -n 1`)
  
## Step 3: Describe the problem:

Freqtrade is well launched but tells me some hours later:
'2019-03-20 09:22:58,649 - freqtrade.freqtradebot - WARNING - Unable to create trade: No currency pairs in whitelist'

Here is what is specified in my configuration file:
        "pair_whitelist": [
            "BTC/USDT"
        ],

When I launch the bot, telegram:
'Searching for USDT pairs to buy and sell based on StaticPairList: ['BTC/USDT']'

So I conclude that a currency pair is well configured....

Do you identify what I could have done wrong ?

Thank you
Regards
Xavier

title: Bot gets stucked in loop when there're restricted markets (BITTREX)
body:
## Step 1: Have you search for this issue before posting it?

I've been looking for some kind of solution for this issue. Even tried all installation ways, and ended up creating a new instance in Binance (an moving some tokens over there). Then I realized at least the conditions.

## Step 2: Describe your environment

I'm running the latest docker image. (I think yesterday's)
  * Branch: Develop
  
## Step 3: Describe the problem:

I have a droplet running the bot inside US, but my Bittrex account is from outside US.
 
The bot gets stucked in the loop of fetching pairs when a pair that is unavailable to trade in the US is whitelisted or spotter vía `VolumePairList`. It never starts to do the math for looking for signals, until that pair is blacklisted or no more in `VolumePairList`.

All the blacklisted in my config.json are the ones that I removed yesterday, and the starts working. It seems like now spotted a new one, details in the log.

So, to work around this, I need to keep watching status table waiting for repeated unchanged tables and then looking at the logs and finally blacklist the pair. And repeat.

title: Bot crashes due to sort key not being populated in ticker data
body:
Experienced on Bittrex. Bot crashes when using VolumePairList and the given sort key is not populated in the ticker data for a given pair. I'm almost certain this is because of some new pair on Bittrex where `quoteVolume` is not populated (yet), since it happened suddenly without any code change and only on Bittrex.

### Relevant code:
```python
tickers = [v for k, v in tickers.items()
           if len(k.split('/')) == 2 and k.split('/')[1] == base_currency]
sorted_tickers = sorted(tickers, reverse=True, key=lambda t: t[key])
```

If `t[key]` is not populated the list cannot be sorted, resulting in a fatal exception.

title: Unable to Perform Sell in dry mode, broken persistance.py
body:
Hi,
Since two days I'm trying to figure out why my fresh installed bot can't perform sell operations on Dry run mode. Even If I perform a force sell all trades stay open.
I suspected a breaking change in SQLAlchemy, so I rollbacked to a previous version, unsucessfully.
So I checked the persistance.py file and tried previous version. And surprisingly the bot is performing normaly if I go back to this commit "cfe00c2f0c118c93e1870567eb75c195bfa91ddd"
I'm investigating to figure out what is hapenning excactly.

title: Minimal ROI value is not really optional, Bot Crash if minimal_roi have no 0 value

labels.name: Documentation
labels.description: Requires updates to documentation

body:
## The problem:
### The "minimal_roi" configuration object is suposed to be optionnal as explained in the doc:

> Most of the strategy files already include the optimal minimal_roi value. This parameter is optional. If you use it in the configuration file, it will take over the minimal_roi value from the strategy file.

Exemple:

>     minimal_roi = {
>         "40": 0.0,
>         "30": 0.01,
>         "20": 0.02,
>         "0": 0.04
>     }

**However, If I remove this parameter in the strategy and config I get this error:**

> 2019-03-06 21:56:56,768 - freqtrade - ERROR - Fatal exception!
> Traceback (most recent call last):
>   File "./freqtrade/main.py", line 45, in main
>     freqtrade = FreqtradeBot(config)
>   File "/home/axel/dev/shatta/framework-dev/private/freqtrade/freqtrade/freqtradebot.py", line 54, in __init__
>     self.strategy: IStrategy = StrategyResolver(self.config).strategy
>   File "/home/axel/dev/shatta/framework-dev/private/freqtrade/freqtrade/resolvers/strategy_resolver.py", line 77, in __init__
>     {int(key): value for (key, value) in self.strategy.minimal_roi.items()}.items(),
> AttributeError: 'ShattaStrategy' object has no attribute 'minimal_roi'

 **Also, If I remove the 0 value key like that:**

>     minimal_roi = {
>         "40": 0.0,
>         "30": 0.01,
>         "20": 0.02,
>     }

**The bot start but crash when trying to check ROI with this error:**
>   File "/freqtrade/freqtrade/freqtradebot.py", line 699, in check_sell
>     should_sell = self.strategy.should_sell(trade, sell_rate, datetime.utcnow(), buy, sell)
>   File "/framework-dev/private/freqtrade/freqtrade/strategy/interface.py", line 273, in should_sell
>     if self.min_roi_reached(trade=trade, current_profit=current_profit, current_time=date):
>   File "/framework-dev/private/freqtrade/freqtrade/strategy/**interface.py", line 349**, in min_roi_reached
>     **roi_entry = max(list(filter(lambda x: trade_dur >= x, self.minimal_roi.keys())))**

### Standalone Python test to reproduce:

> minimal_roi_keys = [0, 20, 30, 40, 50] ## Remove the 0 to trigger error
> trade_dur = 0.3486263354619344
> roi_entry = max(list(filter(lambda x: trade_dur >= x, minimal_roi_keys)))
> print(str(roi_entry))


### Solutions

1. The quick easy solution to temporaly deal with that issue is to make the minimal_roi parameter mandatory and make the "min_roi_reached" work with missing 0. Users who don't want to use ROI can simply put an unrealistic hight value.

2. The other is to make this parameter truly optionnal.

title: Bug: RecursionError in Edge
body:
## Step 2: Describe your environment

  * Branch: Develop
  
## Step 3: Describe the problem:

In the Edge code the _detect_next_stop_or_sell_point() method contains recursive call. This function and the Edge module in the whole if used can fail generating exception "RecursionError: maximum recursion depth exceeded while calling a Python object" after (a bit less than) 1000 recursive calls which is the default limit for python. For an ordinal trader it's inappropriate to dig into unix `setrlimit` and python's `sys.setrecursionlimit` options to allow Edge working. And even worse, exception may happen unexpectedely when Edge is used live rather then being called standalone...

### Steps to reproduce:

It may happen when running Edge on short timeframes, longer timeranges, with custom strategies generating many trades. 

Even with DefaultStrategy: set exchange name: "binance", pair "ETH/BTC", (almost) arbitrary timerange set to default 7d or longer, 1m timeframe. For instance:

```freqtrade edge -r -i 5m --timerange=20190210-20190218```
  
### Relevant code exceptions or logs:

```RecursionError: maximum recursion depth exceeded while calling a Python object```

title: Problems in backtest with trailing_stop

labels.name: Backtest
labels.description: Issues related backtesting.

body:
## Step 1: Have you search for this issue before posting it?
Yes
  
## Step 3: Describe the problem:

While using the bot I've noted some differences from backtest and dry run. I think there are 2 problems in backtest with `trailing_stop:true`:

- at this line https://github.com/freqtrade/freqtrade/blob/788cbb67767cfe7bc8b7166d17ef59e4a94cd85a/freqtrade/strategy/interface.py#L334 should be used the **high** of candle instead of low
- in the same function the trailing stop loss should be adjusted **before** checking if it was reached

Maybe related to #746.

### Steps to reproduce:

  1. backtest with trailing stop active
  
### Observed Results:

  * trades count and timestamp in backtest are not comparable to dry_run
  * trades count and timestamp in backtest should be comparable to dry_run

title: Bug when calculating ROI in backtest
body:
## Step 1: Have you search for this issue before posting it?

If you have discovered a bug in the bot, please [search our issue tracker](https://github.com/freqtrade/freqtrade/issues?q=is%3Aissue). 
If it hasn't been reported, please create a new issue.

## Step 2: Describe your environment

  * Python Version: _____ (`python -V`)
  * CCXT version: _____ (`pip freeze | grep ccxt`)
  * Branch: Master | Develop
  * Last Commit ID: _____ (`git log --format="%H" -n 1`)
  
## Step 3: Describe the problem:

A few days ago user M4DF135H on Slack shared a strategy that showed performance [too good to be true](https://imgur.com/a/W2mq3pn). 

What has caught my attention was the ROI dictionary:
```
minimal_roi = {
    "40": 0.3,
    "30": 0.05,
    "20": 0.07,
    "0": 0.10
}
```

When are used higher values of ROI at higher time durations, the bot fails to calculate the correct rate at which close the trade.

Using `"use_sell_signal": false` and `"ignore_roi_if_buy_signal": false` amplifies the effects.

### Proposed solution:

Change the way bot determines ROI to be applied in function `_get_sell_trade_entry` from `backtesting.py`. Using something like that:
```
# This line don't take in account if profit is > of minimal ROI
# roi_entry = max(list(filter(lambda x: trade_dur > x, self.strategy.minimal_roi.keys())))    
                                                
current_rate = sell_row.high or sell_row.open
current_profit = trade.calc_profit_percent(current_rate)                                             
                            
for duration, threshold in self.strategy.minimal_roi.items():
    if trade_dur <= duration:
        continue
    # The profit must be greater than threshold
    if current_profit > threshold:   
        roi_entry = duration    
        break                        
                            
roi = self.strategy.minimal_roi[roi_entry]
```

I don't know if this is the best approach, I've only adapted code used in `min_roi_reached` in `interface.py`.
  
### Observed Results:

  * What happened? Profit too high
  * What did you expect to happen? Negative profit

### Relevant code exceptions or logs:

  ```
  // paste your log here
  ```

title: Edge

labels.name: Edge
labels.description: Issues related to edge

body:
Edge expectancy only works if allowed risk is 1% (0.01) , anything other its broken. 
Here is a toy to play with it, show the drift. 
```
#some vars
expected_risk_reward = 2
win_rate_pct = 0.7

loss_rate_pct = 0.3
allowed_risk = 0.05
total_capital = 3


# FT expectancy algo
expectancy = expected_risk_reward * win_rate_pct - (1 - win_rate_pct)
print("FT_expectancy", expectancy)
print("----")


# Calculate Expectancy - add to nested dict under 'expectancy'
win_expectancy = win_rate_pct * (total_capital * allowed_risk * expected_risk_reward)
loss_expectancy = loss_rate_pct * (total_capital * allowed_risk)
expectancy = win_expectancy - loss_expectancy
avg_interest = expectancy / total_capital

print("win_expectancy", win_expectancy)
print("loss_expectancy", loss_expectancy)
print("expectancy", expectancy)
print("avg %", avg_interest)
```

Also
docs issue,  R is in here as `profit / loss`  I think its supposed to be RR(risk reward, not R)
https://github.com/freqtrade/freqtrade/blob/develop/docs/edge.md

R is users quote capital at risk in a position.
i.e The amount of quote currency lost at if stopped out, it had nothing to do with profit, its the multiplier.

title: Stop loss ignored if it got changed since the trade was opened.

labels.name: Stoploss
labels.description: Related to stoploss

body:
Environment

Python Version: Python 3.6.6+ (python -V)
CCXT version: ccxt==1.17.399 (pip freeze | grep ccxt)
Branch: Develop
Last Commit ID: 7da127d (git log --format="%H" -n 1)

If there are opened trades and there is a change for the stop loss in the strategy, if the stop loss is set above the current position profitability, the stop loss is ignored.
Eg:

Position is currently at -12%, the stop loss is set at -0.2. The bot is stopped and the stop loss is changed from -0.2 to -0.1 but the position is ignored and not automatically sold although the threshold is set at -0.1 

Every position that was > -0.1 and reaches in the future the said -0.1 stop loss is executed as it should.

title: don't mess with decimals (fixes #1289)
body:
## Summary
Don't mess with decimal precision context.
Since we have ccxt handling communication with ccxt now, lowering precision does not make sense (and is actually dangerous, as shown in #1289).

Solve the issue: #1289

## Quick changelog

- remove setting decimal context - this creates issues with small currencies in ccxt
- Remove skipped test (testing whitelist-refresh is actually tested in `test_acl_pair.py`)

  1. Set bot on some cheap currency (less than 0.00001).
  2. Wait for stoploss
  3. Price on market is wrong

### Observed Results:

  * Price of the bid posted on market was 4e-06
  * Price of the bid posted on market should be 3.73e-06

title: backtesting not always respecting max_open_trades

labels.name: Backtest
labels.description: Issues related backtesting.

body:
## Describe your environment

  * Python Version: 3.7.0 (`python -V`)
  * Branch: Develop
  * Last Commit ID: e0081bcb53b922383c4d99321d973ff8b7d50124 (`git log --format="%H" -n 1`)
  
## Describe the problem:

During backtesting, more than the configured `max_open_trade` at the same time may kept open.

This may happen because the pair-list is looped through - and the "open" date is recorded.
However - if a later pair opens earlier than the previous pairs "open" date, this is not respected, and more trades than `max_open_trades` are opened.

### Steps to reproduce:
  
### Observed Results:

max_open_trades=3

output from trades report:
```
=============================================== LEFT OPEN TRADES REPORT ===============================================
| pair     |   buy count |   avg profit % |   cum profit % |   total profit ETH | avg duration   |   profit |   loss |
|:---------|------------:|---------------:|---------------:|-------------------:|:---------------|---------:|-------:|
| ADA/ETH  |           1 |          -1.10 |          -1.10 |        -0.00109778 | 22:20:00       |        0 |      1 |
| AST/ETH  |           1 |          -2.63 |          -2.63 |        -0.00263732 | 1 day, 1:35:00 |        0 |      1 |
| BCH/ETH  |           1 |          -7.03 |          -7.03 |        -0.00703570 | 1 day, 1:55:00 |        0 |      1 |
| BTG/ETH  |           1 |          -0.70 |          -0.70 |        -0.00070103 | 1 day, 2:35:00 |        0 |      1 |
| DASH/ETH |           1 |          -6.98 |          -6.98 |        -0.00698966 | 1 day, 9:10:00 |        0 |      1 |
| IOTA/ETH |           1 |          -5.47 |          -5.47 |        -0.00547108 | 1 day, 9:25:00 |        0 |      1 |
| TOTAL    |           6 |          -3.98 |         -23.91 |        -0.02393257 | 1 day, 3:50:00 |        0 |      6 |

```
this should not be more than 3 - as no more than 3 should be kept open at any point in time.

## Sample code to analyze backtest-result to check if this really happened:

I used a jupyter notebook for this - but it should also work as script.

``` python
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import json

def load_file(filename):
    with open(filename) as file:
        data = json.load(file)
    columns = ["pair", "profitperc", "opents", "closets", "index", "duration",
        "open_rate", "close_rate", "open_at_end", "sell_reason"]
    df = pd.DataFrame(data, columns=columns)
    
    df['opents'] = pd.to_datetime(df['opents'],
                                    unit='s',
                                    utc=True,
                                    infer_datetime_format=True
                               )
    df['closets'] = pd.to_datetime(df['closets'],
                                    unit='s',
                                    utc=True,
                                    infer_datetime_format=True
                                )
    df['profitabs'] = df['close_rate'] - df['open_rate']
    df = df.sort_values("opents").reset_index(drop=True)
#     df.set_index("index", inplace=True)
    return df

fn = "../freqtrade/user_data/backtest_data/dmca_backtest.json"
df = load_file(fn)


# duplicate rows to be present for each timestamp in 5min frequence
dates = [pd.Series(pd.date_range(row[1].opents, row[1].closets, freq=freq))
         for row in df[['opents', 'closets']].iterrows()]
deltas = [len(x) for x in dates]
dates = pd.Series(pd.concat(dates).values, name='date')

df2 = pd.DataFrame(np.repeat(df.values, deltas, axis=0), columns=df.columns)
df2 = df2.astype(dtype={"opents": "datetime64", "closets": "datetime64"})
df2 = pd.concat([dates, df2], axis=1)
df2 = df2.set_index('date')

# Show count of open trades at any given time
df3 = df2.resample('5min')[['pair']].count()

# Get timestamps where this happened more often
max_open=3
print(df3[df3['pair'] > max_open])


# Show open trades  certian point in time
df2.loc['2018-08-01 01:10:00',]
```

title: Max open trades ignored if multiple buys in same loop
body:
## Step 3: Describe the problem:
If the bot have multiple buy signal on same loop the max open trades parameter will not work. The problematic code  is in the "_process" function:

            if len(trades) < self.config['max_open_trades']:
                state_changed = self.process_maybe_execute_buy()

### Steps to reproduce:

Run the bot with multiple pairs and set the max open trades parameter. Create a buy compulsive strategy. Wait for the bot to by a batch of coins.
  
### Observed Results:
The bot will buy on all buy signals even if the maximum open teades limit is reached.

### Solution
The "max_open_trades" should be checked in the "create_trade" function.

body:
## Describe your environment

  * Python Version: 3.6.6 (`python -V`)
  * Branch: Develop
  * Last Commit ID: 0b3190552ec02b9a5b03dbe60896af06462d36bb
  
## Describe the problem:

running the bot with --dynamic-whitelist 20 picked up "HOT/BTC" today. 
it's a coin [listed today](https://support.binance.com/hc/en-us/articles/360007931511-Binance-Will-List-Holo-HOT-on-2018-07-24)

This coin should not be picked up as it does not have any historic candles, so signals may fluctuate randomly without control.
Also i don't understand how it can be used as there is a check for volume in place, and i doubt it is in the top20 coins for the last 24 hours.

this is the result from today - it did 32 trades in the last ~12 hours - probably all buying / selling right away, at least that's how i noticed it in the last hour.



![2018-07-24-165421_526x448_scrot](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5024695/43150618-412e229c-8f62-11e8-991c-f230a2303e89.png)

A check for "is listed since 100 x interval" should be implemented to make sure there is enough historic candles to generate signals safely.

title: Dry test only open 5-8 trades, when buy =1 is on tens of pairs.
body: I've moved my QA into dry test / live. The volume of trades seen in Backtest are realistic, but FT in Dry and Live only open 5-10 of these. This issue is to highlight the bot quickly ties itself up processing only open trades when 5-8 trades are open, and ignores other pairs. Thus not discovering their Buy =1 signal, not buying. When the 5-9 open trades receive SELL =1 the bot starts processing the pairs that were ignored. This manifests itself as only ever having a few - 7/8 open trades and then ignoring all other buy opportunities. This is perfect world, the strategy has no processing overhead. The concurrency falls when over head is higher. In live there a many exampled of users seeing only 1-4 pairs open when expecting open trades against many tens of pairs. Below describes the work flow in the linked video. Test scenarion 53 pairs, max trades 53, strategy returns 0 on even minutes, 1 on odd - no delay. Ill paraphrase but the workflow of the bot in dry test quickly becomes thus. **odd minute - sell =1** 1) tests though loop of pairs while sell = 1 / buy = 0, maybe 1-2 seconds per pair. **even minute - buy = 1** 2) - opens first trade. Time to process 1 second tends to trade 1 - opens second trade : Time to process 4 seconds tends to trade 1 tends to trade 2 - opens third trade : Time to process 6 seconds tends to trade 1 tends to trade 2 tends to trade 3 ...... trade 7 takes 12 seconds to open. No more pairs are open. 3) The bot spends an ever increasing time managing open trades and during this time does not process the "Other pairs" **Even minute - Sell = 1** 4) The bot notices the change, - as now no longer solely focuses on the open pairs - processes other pairs from the 53 **even minute - buy = 1** 5) The 7 sold open trades now show in trades DB ,, first trade shows as closed on exactly even minute in the trades db when buy =1 others close very soon after (2 seconds) (but not when they are sell-1, when flipped back to buy =1 6) New trades begin to open again - as per step 2. It is the same pairs to open. 7) repeat. A video of the issue. https://highfrequencybot.slack.com/files/UAU4J8LU9/FBTQFU431/ft_drytest.mp4

title: Dry Test / Live - trades are sold after buy =1(entry) > sell = 1 > buy =1(exit)
body: I've moved my QA into dry test / live. There are a number of issues seen that directly impact profitability which are also confirmed anecdotally by users in Slack. Test scenarion 53 pairs, max trades 53, strategy returns 0 on even minutes, 1 on odd - no delay. Ill paraphrase but the workflow of the bot in dry test quickly becomes thus. **odd minute - sell =1** 1) tests though loop of pairs while sell = 1 / buy = 0, maybe 1-2 seconds per pair. **even minute - buy = 1** 2) - opens first trade. Time to process 1 second tends to trade 1 - opens second trade : Time to process 4 seconds tends to trade 1 tends to trade 2 - opens third trade : Time to process 6 seconds tends to trade 1 tends to trade 2 tends to trade 3 ...... trade 7 takes 12 seconds to open. No more pairs are open. 3) The bot spends an ever increasing time managing open trades and during this time does not process the "Other pairs" **Even minute - Sell = 1** 4) The bot notices the change, - as now no longer solely focuses on the open pairs - processes other pairs from the 53 - none of the 7 pairs open i trade are sold...... **They should be sold** **even minute - buy = 1** 5) The 7 open trades now close ,, first trade closes on exacly even minute when buy =1 others close very soon after (2 seconds) (but not when they are sell-1, when flipped back to buy =1 6) New trades begin to open again - as per step 2. It is the same pairs to open. 7) repeat. In terms of issues there are a few The most important for this issue is trades are not sold on sell=1 but when flipping from buy=1 to sell =1 and back to buy =1. This ensures poor trading. A video of the issue. https://highfrequencybot.slack.com/files/UAU4J8LU9/FBTQFU431/ft_drytest.mp4

title: Back test calculates duration wrong

title: BUG: Back test, analyse.py strips last candle as incomplete, in BT its never incomplete.

labels.name: Backtest
labels.description: Issues related backtesting.

body:
In Backtest analyse.py is striping the last candle of the dataframe as incomplete. 
No candle data in backtest is incomplete so this is bug behaviour. 

`  frame.drop(frame.tail(1).index, inplace=True)     # eliminate partial candle`

This effectively means we've triggered our buy/sell/or stop on current bar which we then throw away before calculating returns on purchase/sale.

The leads to false (past) pricing presented when opening/closing a trade

As example impact to results with last candle stripped and without. 
Same data/strategy etc.

> ======================================== BACKTESTING REPORT =========================================
> | pair     |   buy count |   avg profit % |   total profit USDT |   avg duration |   profit |   loss |
> |:---------|------------:|---------------:|--------------------:|---------------:|---------:|-------:|

> | TOTAL    |           1 |          -0.20 |         -0.00203731 |          360.0 |        0 |      1 |
> 

And with the guilty line hashed out:

title: Config-dict not always uptodate

labels.name: Enhancement
labels.description: Enhancements to the bot. Get lower priority than bugs by default.

body:
## Describe your environment

  * Python Version: 3.6.6 (`python -V`)
  * CCXT version: `not relevant`
  * Branch: Develop
  * Last Commit ID: 7c8c8e83d3d0dd20bedb645213f55d4991611635
  
## Describe the problem:

the config-dictionary does not always have the correct values, which can lead to bugs
noticed in #979 - not having the ticker-interval configured in the configuration leaves this entry blank, as it's comming from the strategy.

I think loading the strategy should update the config-dict with the "used" value (not just for `ticker_interval` - but also for `minimal_roi`, `stoploss`, ... - so using the config-object guarantees the correct values.

This would also elliminate the need for some functions in `analyze.py`, as the config-object (which is available in avery class in the bot) gives what is needed.

Potential candidates for removal:
https://github.com/freqtrade/freqtrade/blob/7c8c8e83d3d0dd20bedb645213f55d4991611635/freqtrade/analyze.py#L93-L105

title: 50% of time bot labels valid candle as out of date, returns false false
body: For context im using 2hr candles. The time is 09:26AM The last closed candle is [O:6am - C:8am] The open candle is [O:8am - (to be closed 10am) Summary: Bot labels valid candle as out of date, returns false false Suggested fix: Analyse.py change from / to ``` if signal_date < (arrow.utcnow() - timedelta(minutes=(interval_minutes + 5))): if signal_date < (arrow.utcnow() - timedelta(minutes=(interval_minutes + interval_minutes + 5))): ``` Background: The bot currently strips incomplete candles, which it classifies as the last candle in ticker_hist from the exchange. This is as the exchange provides the open/incomplete candle as the last, it would be dangerous to present this to a strategy as OLHC - as example ta-lib would process the incomplete data as a valid 'close' causing bad/unintended entry/exit conditions. Issue: The bot wrongly labels data as old in the output log after it has stripped the last candle. e.g. ` freqtrade.analyze - WARNING - Outdated history for pair LTC/BTC. Last tick is 206 minutes old` Root cause analysis: Analysis shows the [O:6am - C:8am] is the last in the dataframe. This candle will be valid until the [0:8am - C:10:am] candle closes. There is a false test in analyse.py, where signal_date is 6am and interval is 120m (2hours) `if signal_date < (arrow.utcnow() - timedelta(minutes=(interval_minutes + 5))):` This states that after 8:05 the candle will be marked as bad. The candle should be accepted until at least 10:00 + period of grace. (5mins) Supporting:

title: Only allow timeframes supported by the exchange
body: Bot should on startup check that the exchange chosen has the ticker timeframe available chosen in the config/strategy. Now the bot crashes if the ticker is not available.

title: backtest opens with trade open (open open) bug

labels.name: Backtest
labels.description: Issues related backtesting.

body: This issue was found during testing of PR 855 but is a standalone issue (probably) so im raising a separate ticket. #855 Freqtrade backtest has a bug No matter the timerange passed freqtrade opens with a trade in an open state. I have applied the lookahead patch from #855 For timeranges yyyymmdd-yyyymmdd these false trades are open at midnight exactly. I've also passed a timestamp range from 18:00 and it also starts with a trade open. Subsequent trades found by FreqTrade in the range align perfectly with what Tradingview lists. The start with a trade open bug throws the profit/drawdown results for the period. Examples of the **(open open)** bug and aligning with TV. Example using timestamp to set the range to 18:00 start.

title: Missed or badly triggered computed Actions: BUY and SELL. Significant Difference Between Backtest and LIVE.

labels.name: Enhancement
labels.description: Enhancements to the bot. Get lower priority than bugs by default.

labels.name: Good first issue
labels.description: Good issues to get familiar and start contributing to freqtrade

labels.name: Backtest
labels.description: Issues related backtesting.

body: **## Step 2: Describe your environment** * Python Version: Python 3.6.4 * Branch: Develop * Last Commit ID: b0536db (`git log --format="%H" -n 1`) **## Step 3: Describe the problem:** Hi everyone, I decided to finaly create an issue because i'm struggling with a problem since a few weeks: There is an important difference between the signal that are computed on Backtest and the reality of actions in Live. After a few observation I can tell that this is not related to a normal lag due to the network. The behavior seems to occur when a trigger is slightly triggered. **Exemple:** Sell When "Close Under Open Of Previous Candle" dataframe['close'] < dataframe['open'].shift() _Theoricaly Failing case_ 0.00005155 < 0.00005156 (Those values are too close, the condition is not fullfilled) _Theoricaly Working case_ 0.00005155 < 0.00005160 (the gap between the two value is large enought, the condition is fullfilled) ### Steps to reproduce: 1. Use 1 minute Time frame 2. launch freqtrade on live with a strategy that use directly price or averages to trigger BUY or SELL actions 3. Wait for a price movement that "slightly" correspond to the signal (BUY or SELL) 4. The signal is not triggered or is badly triggered . 5. When a few moment later there is a bigger price move that trigger the signal more Frankly, the signal is triggered. ### Observed Results: * What happened? The signal is not triggered sometimes, when there is a small gap between compared values that are used to take the descision * What did you expect to happen? The signal should be triggered in live more or less at the same moment that is computed on the backtest (less than 1min drift tolerated on live) ### Relevant code exceptions or logs: Note: On plot-dataframe I modified the code to display only the SELLs that are consecutive to BUYs, to have more clarity. ### Suspected cause Loss of prescision due to python floating point: the problem with that theory is that I don't understand why the backtest is working as expected. The problem should be also present in that case... ### What I tried to fix that issue 1- Convert all collumns related to triggers to Decimal 2- Rise Ta-lib prescision (https://github.com/mrjbq7/ta-lib/issues/151) The issue is still present. Thank you for your help. Regards, Axel

title: Calculation of profit percentage in /profit
body:
## Describe your environment

  * Python Version: Python 3.6.5 (`python -V`)
  * Branch: Develop / feat/objectify-ccxt (not really relevant)
  * Last Commit ID: 743a1f16047c66dbd4c60516172e3d5d2fe7ee78 
 
## Describe the problem:

The profit percentage in the output of `/profit` from Telegram seems to be wrong.

Assuming the bot did 40 trades (30 closed) with a stake of 0.02 BTC and made a total of 0.00454026 BTC profit - it invested / risked a total of 0.06 (30 * 0.02) for closed trades.

The following output from Telegram:
```
ROI: Close trades
∙ 0.00454026 BTC (22.72%)
∙ 40.387 USD
ROI: All trades
∙ -0.00082832 BTC (-4.15%)
∙ -7.368 USD
Total Trade Count: 40
First Trade opened: a day ago
Latest Trade opened: an hour ago
Avg. Duration: 4:14:28
Best Performing: DNT/BTC: 5.71%
```

It's showing a profit of 22.72% for closed trades. 

The calculation is taking each trade individually and calculating the percentage for each trade, suming these percentages. [rpc.py#L212](https://github.com/gcarq/freqtrade/blob/develop/freqtrade/rpc/rpc.py#L212).

While this calculation method is correct for the absolute profit, it seems wrong to me for the percentage as it shows a way higher gain than what really was won.

## Correct calculation:
Correct calculation should show something as follows:
Total investment: 0.6 BTC
profit:  0.00454026
profit-Percentage: 0.756%
 
There are a few possibilities - with slight differences in the calculation method and results. I'm not sure which of the possibilities is the correct way to aggregate percentage gains:

### Potential solution: average
instead of using `profit_closed_percent = round(sum(profit_closed_percent) * 100, 2)` - use `profit_closed_percent = round(mean(profit_closed_percent) * 100, 2)`.

in the above example, this results in a profit percentage of 0.757%.
the difference in the 3rd decimal appears to be a Rounding difference.

### potential solution: total_stake
instead of using `profit_closed_percent = round(sum(profit_closed_percent) * 100, 2)`, use 
something as follows - by calculating the profit based on total stake and total profit
``` python
profit_closed_percent = round(((total_stake_closed_coins + profit_closed_coin) / total_stake) * 100, 2)
```

### potential solution: max_stake
use the stake * max open trades (max risk) to do the calculation
``` python
total_stake = stake * max_open_trades # maximum risked 
profit_closed_percent = round(((total_stake_closed_coins + profit_closed_coin) / total_stake) * 100, 2)
```

I'm absolutely not sure which calculation is the correct one.
The main purpose of this ticket is to get input on which calculation would be the correct approach.

#230

title: [ccxt] Fee calculation causes Binance selling to fail

labels.name: CCXT
labels.description: Issues related to communication with ccxt (may or may not be caused by upstream issues)

body:
### The problem
When running the bot on Binance using the ccxt library (#230) and BNB fees disabled, the bot will show an InsufficientFunds error when trying to sell a previously opened trade.

This is caused by the difference in fee calculation between Binance and Bittrex. The bot is programmed assuming that the fees are subtracted from the currency you are exchanging **from**. On Binance and most other exchanges, fees are subtracted from the currency  you are exchaning **to** For instance, say you have 1 ETH and are buying 0.5 LTC at a rate of 1 LTC/ETH, with 1% fees. 

**On Bittrex (expected and actual):**
1 ETH -> (buy 0.5 LTC) -> 0.495 ETH, 0.5 LTC ->  (sell 0.5 LTC)  -> 0.99 ETH

**On Binance (expected):**
1 ETH -> (buy 0.5 LTC) -> 0.5 ETH, 0.495 LTC ->  (sell 0.495 LTC)  -> 0.99005 ETH (0.5 + (1-0.01)*0.495)

**On Binance (actual):**
1 ETH -> (buy 0.5 LTC) -> 0.5 ETH, 0.495 LTC ->  (sell 0.5 LTC)  -> **Insufficient funds**

**On Binance with BNB fees (expected and actual):**
1 ETH, 1 BNB -> (buy 0.5 LTC) -> 0.5 ETH, 0.5 LTC, 0.99... BNB ->  (sell 0.5 LTC)  -> 1 ETH, 0.98... BNB

This issue is also a more general problem that will affect other exchanges, and the fee handling/calculation should be overhauled to make fewer assumptions.

The function `calculate_fee` from ccxt returns information about where the fee was subtracted, but does not seem to handle BNB fees. For example, selling 0.5 LTC to ETH with 0.1% fees correctly gives the below output, which shows that fees are subtracted from LTC when buying and ETH when selling. But it does not make any request to Binance and so does not know if you have BNB fees enabled.

```
>>> import ccxt
>>> bin = ccxt.binance()
>>> bin.load_markets()
>>> bin.calculate_fee(symbol='LTC/ETH', type='limit', side='buy', amount=0.5, price=1)

{
  'type': 'taker',
  'currency': 'LTC',
  'rate': 0.001,
  'cost': 0.0005
}

>>> bin.calculate_fee(symbol='LTC/ETH', type='limit', side='sell', amount=0.5, price=1) 

{
  'type': 'taker', 
  'currency': 'ETH',
  'rate': 0.001, 
  'cost': 0.0005
}
```

### Environment
Branch: feat/objectify-ccxt

### Steps to reproduce:

  1. Disable BNB fees on your account on Binance
  2. Run the bot normally (not in dry run mode) and wait until it tries to make a sell
  3. Insufficient funds error

  ```
2018-04-11 12:39:31,695 - freqtrade - INFO - DEBUG: Tyring to sell pair NEO/BTC... 
2018-04-11 12:39:31,861 - freqtrade - WARNING - Got Insufficient funds to create limit sell order on market NEO/BTC.Tried to sell amount 0.59 at rate 0.007882 (total 0.00465038).Message: binance {"code":-2010,"msg":"Account has insufficient balance for requested action."} in _process(), retrying in 30 seconds...
  ```

### Intended outcome

The bot should compensate for any amount lost for fees after the buy order is fully filled, no matter where the fees come from (target, base, or elsewhere, like BNB).

### Possible solutions

The fee could possibly be extracted from the order object, but this is incomplete so far. See [ccxt docs](http://ccxt.readthedocs.io/en/latest/manual.html#order-structure)

Since you are not sure until after the trade where the fees came from, the closed buy order could be queried and the correct amount updated in the bot database. For BNB fees this is particularily true, since there is no way to know if the user is running BNB fees enabled or not, or if there is sufficient BNB in the account, before the order is placed.

`calculate_fee` could also be used in some way to prevent making requests on exchanges where it makes sense, but is less bulletproof than actually checking after the order is filled.

title: Buggy aggregation of backtesting data
body:
## Step 2: Environment

  * Python Version: 3.6.2 (`python -V`)
  * Branch: Develop
  
## Step 3: Describe the problem:

*Refreshing backtesting data can lead to incorrect json files, this is even more visible when using long tickers (>1h for example)*

```
    {
        "O": 5.16e-06,
        "H": 5.24e-06,
        "L": 5.14e-06,
        "C": 5.22e-06,
        "V": 3566325.80403886,
        "T": "2018-03-28T05:00:00",
        "BV": 18.52401847
    },
    {
        "O": 5.16e-06,
        "H": 5.24e-06,
        "L": 5.14e-06,
        "C": 5.2e-06,
        "V": 3723206.94171314,
        "T": "2018-03-28T05:00:00",
        "BV": 19.34334127
    }
```

### Observed Results:

  * The last timestamp is available 2 times
  * What did you expect to happen, only the most uptodate ticker should be present (the one with the biggest Volume and biggest BaseVolume)
   * We should either fix the backtesting data insertion or sanitized the dataframe just after fetching it

### Relevant code exceptions or logs:

The insertion is not making use of the timestamp, so if the same timestamp with different OHLC data is fetched it will be inserted in the JSON file.


  ```
# FIX: 20180110, suggest rename interval to tick_interval
def download_backtesting_testdata(datadir: str, pair: str, interval: int = 5) -> bool:
    """
    Download the latest 1 and 5 ticker intervals from Bittrex for the pairs passed in parameters
    Based on @Rybolov work: https://github.com/rybolov/freqtrade-data
    :param pairs: list of pairs to download
    :return: bool
    """

    path = make_testdata_path(datadir)
    logger.info('Download the pair: "{pair}", Interval: {interval} min'.format(
        pair=pair,
        interval=interval,
    ))

    filepair = pair.replace("-", "_")
    filename = os.path.join(path, '{pair}-{interval}.json'.format(
        pair=filepair,
        interval=interval,
    ))

    if os.path.isfile(filename):
        with open(filename, "rt") as fp:
            data = json.load(fp)
        logger.debug("Current Start: {}".format(data[1]['T']))
        logger.debug("Current End: {}".format(data[-1:][0]['T']))
    else:
        data = []
        logger.debug("Current Start: None")
        logger.debug("Current End: None")

    new_data = get_ticker_history(pair=pair, tick_interval=int(interval))
    for row in new_data:
        if row not in data:
            data.append(row)
    logger.debug("New Start: {}".format(data[1]['T']))
    logger.debug("New End: {}".format(data[-1:][0]['T']))
    data = sorted(data, key=lambda data: data['T'])

    misc.file_dump_json(filename, data)

    return True

  ```

title: Hyperopt documentation

labels.name: Good first issue
labels.description: Good issues to get familiar and start contributing to freqtrade

labels.name: Hyperopt
labels.description: Hyperopt related issues and pull requests

body:
## describe your environment:
python3.6
Branch develop 
last commit: ebe1d3647f2547243b5a064775d82f0833ca60a6
## Describe the problem:
The documentation for [hyperopt](https://github.com/gcarq/freqtrade/blob/develop/docs/hyperopt.md) seems outdated.
It mentiones changing / adding the hyeropt spaces in the strategy file - however the links to the related code in the test-strategy don't point to the correct lines, which seem to have been refactored / removed from the test-strategy in commit [30abebf](https://github.com/gcarq/freqtrade/commit/30abebfe65badbd5083f0d0b7b07a082afad7667).

Also, the `spaces` seems to have been moved into the hyperopt file (https://github.com/gcarq/freqtrade/blob/develop/freqtrade/optimize/hyperopt.py) - which i think should not be changed as part of user optimization of a strategy. If i understood hyperopt correctly, then spaces should be adjusted to match the lines used in your strategy - which is impossible without modifying a core / commited file.

The code in hyperopt does not seem to load spaces from any other user-data file other than hyperopt_optimize_conf - which is only the configuration and does not contain spaces or other hyperopt modifieable parameters.

title: Backtesting results far from production performance

body:
## Step 2: Describe your environment

  * Python Version: 3.6.4 (`python -V`)
  * Branch: Develop
  * Last Commit ID: ac006e0d52e5bd1ad04acbf1b3891b3125c98668 (`git log --format="%H" -n 1`)
 
## Step 3: Describe the problem:
We know the backtesting cannot 100% right with a real production environment, a lot of parameters cannot be simulated. But we expect the backtesting to be close to the truth.

To understand if the backtesting is good enough, I have made an experience. 
I have run a bot in production for 11 days without interruption, without changing any parameters. Then I have backtested the same period with the exact same strategy, parameters, and crypto pairs.

#### Here the result:
Prod result:  **107 trades** for a profit of **0.00182468 BTC**
Backtesting: **246 trades** for a profit of **0.01000823 BTC**

A difference of 129% between Backtesting and Prod trades numbers.

### Steps to reproduce:

  1. Update your ticker `python3 ./freqtrade/main.py -c user_data/config-prod.json --datadir user_data/data/ -s prod_strategy backtesting --realistic-simulation -r`
  2. Extract only the period you want, for that I am using a script I have made ([here](https://github.com/glonlas/freqtrade-strategies/blob/master/scripts/extract_data.py)), Doc [here](#how-did-you-build-dataset)
  3. Run backtesting `python3 ./freqtrade/main.py -c user_data/config-prod.json --datadir user_data/data/2018-01-18_2018-01-29 -s prod_strategy backtesting --realistic-simulation`

title: service file not working
body:
The latest commits have broken the systemd service file. With some debugging and modification it works. `user_data` is one culprit and also not installing as a module makes it tricky. I was able to workaround but it's not ideal:

### Workaround

Copy `freqtrade` script to your virtualenv bin dir. In my case:

`cp /home/freqtrade/freqtrade/bin/freqtrade /home/freqtrade/freqtrade/.env/bin/`

Make the following adjustments:

#### `~/.config/systemd/user/freqtrade.service`

```systemd
[Unit]
Description=FreqTrade Daemon
After=network.target

[Service]
WorkingDirectory=%h/freqtrade
ExecStart=/home/freqtrade/freqtrade/.env/bin/freqtrade --dynamic-whitelist 50
Restart=on-failure
EnvironmentFile=/home/freqtrade/freqtrade.env

[Install]
WantedBy=default.target
```

#### `~/freqtrade.env`

````
PATH=/home/freqtrade/freqtrade/.env/bin:/usr/local/bin:/usr/bin:/bin
PYTHONIOENCODING=utf-8
PYTHONPATH=/home/freqtrade/freqtrade
VIRTUAL_ENV=/home/freqtrade/freqtrade/.env
````

The Bot buys the coin with a price (X). But calculating the current Profit ( on Status & ROI check) with the actual open rate(Y) at the time of buying.

title: Persistent Fail on `ORDER_NOT_OPEN` OperationalException
body:
## Environment

  * Python Version: Python 3.6.3
  * Branch: Develop
  * Last Commit ID: 1fe86656e168a256c237e55a013fbc22ac75b1c2
 
## Problem

Bot crashes and can't be restarted. 


### Steps to reproduce:

1. Notice stalled trade with profit that doesn't match bittrex
   `121  BTC_XCP   1 d      0.23%`
2. Try `/forcesell 121` multiple times without success
3. Delete order manually on bittrex hours later.
4. Bot crashes and cannot be restarted.

### Output


>Status: Got OperationalException:

title: Buggy get_ticker
body: The get_ticker method of the bittrex class checks for certain fields to be present in the exchange answer. For the ticker the expected fields are Ask,Bid,Last. However the way the test is written is checking for a non zero value, thus leading to DecodingContentException when one of the previous fields is zero

title: Hyperopt error when no result
body:
## Step 2: Describe your environment

  * Python Version: 3.6.3 (`python -V`)
  * Branch: Develop
  * Last Commit ID: a18019e8e2c339230767d40a1633534482a882b9 (`git log --format="%H" -n 1`)
 
## Step 3: Describe the problem:
Hyperopt throws an error when it is not able to find a result. It happens when we try with very few epochs (like `-e 5`).

### Steps to reproduce:

  1. Execute many times hyperopt with less than 5 epochs: `python3 ./freqtrade/main.py -c config.json hyperopt -e 5`
  2. You will have some hyperopt with a result, until one will fail

### Observed Results:

  * **What happened?** When Hyperopt is too tired with ridiculous attempts with tiny epochs it throws to us the error: `ValueError: attempt to get argmin of an empty sequence`. Because of that our Travis-CI fails time to time.
  * **What did you expect to happen?** We are expecting Hyperopt to return an empty result and be sorry to haven't be able to find something. Not to throw an exception to us.

title: The status  command is slow
body: With many trades in progress, the /Status command is slow, this is due to the fact that it fetches the latest value from the exchange, we should cache this value has it it being already fetched in _process

title: Fix issue #248: missing configuration when executing /forcesell
body:
Fix for issue #248 

## What is the issue
When `telegram._forcesell()`is executed it call `main.execute_sell()` outside of the main context. `main.py` populate the _CONF. However; when `_forcesell()` called `main.execute_sell()` _CONF is empty `{}` and the function cannot find what crypto-currency and fiat currency must be used.

## Comment
This is not a beautiful workaround, I am not proud of it, but a redesigning of main.py and telegram.py will be necessary for a better integration. Any better solution is welcome.

title: Retry on "Got invalid response" during backtesting
body:
Backtesting:
Example: `requests.exceptions.ContentDecodingError: Got invalid response from bittrex params=(BTC_NAUT)` this is error should be skipped and the coin marked as "N/A" on the results.

Else every "Got invalid response" breaks the backtest routine and there are many coins not working.

Ideal would be a mark in the database so the bot check every x hours if the coin is now available if so send a notification via telegram if not keep ignoring.

title: catch MIN_TRADE_REQUIREMENT_NOT_MET as non-critical exception
body:
This PR catches `MIN_TRADE_REQUIREMENT_NOT_MET` as non fatal exception.

The root cause will be fixed in another PR.
Bittrex has a minimum trade value of  100,000 Satoshis [(src)](https://support.bittrex.com/hc/en-us/articles/115003004171-What-are-my-trade-limits-), since our fee calculation is now more precise it could happen that we try to create an invalid LIMIT_BUY order. This happens especially with coins that are only worth some satoshis. @glonlas My assumption is that this happens because of an precision rounding error:
```

title: Backtesting: wrong AVG profit
body:
Hello,

I ran a backtesting with a `Using stake_amount: 0.001`, on the backtesting result of the, I saw that:

```
pair         buy count  avg profit    total profit       avg duration
---------  -----------  ------------  ---------------  --------------
BTC_XEM              1  2.49%         0.02490797 BTC            25
```

However, if the bot is doing only 1 trade at `0.001 BTC` and get a total profit of `0.02490797 BTC`. the result cannot be 2.49% (0.00249). Because 2.49% of 0.001 = 0.0010249 `0.001+(0.001*0.0249)`

Instead of 2.49% we have 249%.
The issue seems to come from here: https://github.com/gcarq/freqtrade/blob/develop/freqtrade/optimize/backtesting.py#L50

title: Wrong fee calculation
body:
Hi guys,

I think the way we calculate fees are wrong in `persistence::calc_profit()`.
Bittrex takes 0.25% (0.0025) on each transaction (buy and sell). But the behavior is different if it is a buy or a sell.

**Buy behavior:** Bittrex will take the fee from your BTC wallet, not deduct it from the trade. That means it always cost us more BTC than the order we made (Add fees on top of the order)
**Buy formula** = `(#unit * open_rate) + ((#unit * open_rate)* 0.0025)`

**Sell behavior:** Bittrex will deduct fees from your order result. That means we always get less than the amount we sell (Deduct fee from the profit/loss)
**Sell formula =** `(#unit * close_rate) - ((#unit * close_rate)* 0.0025)`

**Percentage profit/loss:** `(Sell result / Buy result) - 1`

### Example:
I buy one coin at `0.00258580` (Open rate) then I will sell it at `0.00279266` (Close rate)

Buy = `(1 * 0.00258580) + ((1 * 0.00258580)* 0.0025)` = 0.002592265 BTC
Sell = `(1 * 0.00279266) - ((1 * 0.00279266)* 0.0025)` = 0.002785682 BTC
Profit = `0.002785682 - 0.002592265` = +0.000193417 BTC
Percentage profit/loss = `(0.002785682 / 0.002592265) - 1` = 0.0746 (7.46%)

## Issue in the way fee are calculated in the code
During a Trade by doing `fee=exchange.get_fee() * 2,` we do not apply the right amount a fees.
Source: https://github.com/gcarq/freqtrade/blob/b77fad6e5f204cb3593c33bc650c0317a97b213b/freqtrade/main.py#L233

The formula on `calc_profit()`does not seem right.
Source: https://github.com/gcarq/freqtrade/blob/b77fad6e5f204cb3593c33bc650c0317a97b213b/freqtrade/persistence.py#L110-L119

**Can we have a unit-test to see I am wrong on the fee calculation?**

title: Loop stops without error on master branch
body:
I've now noticed this twice in the past two days, and I haven't seen an error leading up to the failure of the main loop that checks for entry positions.  Note, this is with 2 trades open, when my settings have a maximum of 5, so there are plenty of slots available.  This occurs after about 17 hours or so of successfully running the bot in dry_run mode.

When finally shutting down the bot, I see a number of errors finally show up.  My guess is, these are related to the loop stopping.  Here is the output from my console, it's currently 11:51am, and the loop last updated at 7:03am.

title: Sell due to loss, bot buys the same currency
body: I set up loss limit to 5%, bot bought NEO, after a little while loss was 5.24% so bot sold NEO and right after that (few seconds later) bot bought NEO again. Does that make sense? If so - can we block that somehow? If not - can we block that somehow?

title: Race Condition: Buy Order Not Complete Before Sell Order
body:
If you make a buy and the order is not complete before you have a race condition and the bot stops.

2 options to resolve:
1 Check the wallet to make sure that sufficient coins are available.  This makes other problem scenarios: buy never completes, price changes drastically before the buy is complete, etc.  Maybe can do something like cancel the pending order, and sell what coins are available.
2 check order status and cancel a buy after a certain time if it's not fulfilled.  If the order is partial, then update the order table with the appropriate quantity.  This can also be used with a wallet check to make sure there is sufficient coins available.

title: Whitelist pair after sale
body: Currently, the purchased pair is still removed from the whitelist even after it's sold. In my mind it would make sense if it is whitelisted again once sold. Would make a pull request on this, but my limited python skills keep me from seeing how to ideally get the whitelist object into execute_sell.

title: Sell amount equal to amount purchased
body: At the moment, the bot sells whatever the balance is for the given pair on the exchange. It would be nice to have an option to sell only the amount of coin previously purchased by the bot. This way, freqtrade won't accidentally mess with whatever trades I am doing manually on the side.
